I'm trans nb (more specifically Agender) and I came out to someone who I thought was a close friend of mine and told them to call me by a different name and pronouns. They said no, due to their religious beliefs, and that hurt but I put up with it because tons of people who I don't know well enough to come out to would call be by the wrong stuff (and I'm sure they would continue to even if I came out). A little later I asked a substitute teacher to call be by the right name (my dead name is still in the attendance sheet) and other kids started to make fun of me. My friend, much to my shock and horror, joined in on this mockery. Upset by this I pointed out how they went along with something made to cause harm to me but refused to respect who I am. They replied by saying I know why they don't call me that stuff and continued to be rude. I finally realized they have no respect for me as a human being with thoughts and feelings and I have cut off my relationship with them.

Hey chase, you said something about that us trans people often try to find validation by other people by them calling us the right pronouns, and that it might be a little problematic, but i dont think thats the reason why we want everyone to call us the right pronouns. I think its more like that we are for example male and we want other people to call us male; because we are. Not because we want to feel good about ourselves and feel valid, but just because we _are_. I dont want people to call me he because like lets say, they wanna make me feel good, like "oh you feel like a boy let me be nice to you and call you he". Its more like just with cis people we dont call them the right pronouns to validate them but just simply because those _are_ their pronouns.

I am nonbinary and my mom says she is fine with it but she wont call me my name and she wont call me my pronouns...

In my experience people found it harder to adjust to different pronouns than to a new name, even after my friends had gotten used to my new name and never messed that up they'd still get the pronouns wrong sometimes, I think that might be because they were thinking more about the name whereas pronouns are just automatic, we don't really think about them before we say them usually. 
It sucks when someone uses the wrong pronouns, but if I know they're trying and just made a mistake I don't mind nearly as much, especially if they correct themselves. 
Also I totally agree on not making a big deal of apologising, a quick sorry is good, but I'd rather no apology that a massive declaration about it. What I really hate is when someone goes into a whole speech about how difficult it is for them because they've known me for years as she and it's so hard and all that... I understand that it's hard, I'm not expecting anyone to be perfect straight away, just please try, and don't try to make me feel guilty for putting you to sooo much trouble if I correct you.

What do you do when you've sat one of your parents down multiple times crying telling them that it hurts you every time they misgender you but the only real response you've gotten from them is "I just don't like people telling me what to say"... and what do you do when someone who you'll have to associate with your whole life has said that they refuse to call you the correct name and pronouns?
I am FTM it's hard for my husband and my mom to call me He now or by my name my mom will call me Owen online .
Love your channel Chase!

I remember going to a rally for my church youth group, and when we got back, my sponsor commended and thanked me for being so insistent and good about reminding/informing people on how to refer to me when it came to pronouns. At the rallies, you're split up into family groups, and the groups will be mixes of all the chapters. My sponsor was put in a group with a young trans boy, and any time they used "she" or "her," the kid would just look annoyed. He didn't actually say "please refer to me as male," he just expected everyone to know. Please, PLEASE don't do this. Don't expect people to know right away how to treat you. It's like expecting a doctor to know you're allergic to a certain medicine without telling them (okay maybe not that extreme, but you get it). Even if you're shy and don't feel comfortable speaking out like this, please don't be mad at people for making this mistake. They don't know they're making the mistake. I promise you, most of the time, they're not trying to hurt you and don't want to hurt you. It's impossible to fix a problem you don't know you have.

I'm honestly very happy that you're pushing for a more understanding approach to being accidentally misgendered. I am a cis woman and have a friend that I have known since I was about 9-10 years old, and they used to go by he/him pronouns but recently told me that they identify as nonbinary. While my perception changed about them, as in I did not see them fall under the binary, it took some time to decondition myself from using the wrong pronouns and learning to use they/them. I think it's a matter of the mind most of the time. It's really reconditioning yourself to use the proper words. Your tip actually helped me out. I think you mentioned it in the Your So Brave podcast some episodes ago, and honestly I haven't made the mistake of misgendering them since then.
Also, I found that the best way to find out how to handle accidentally misgendering someone is by doing what you said: apologizing real quick on the spot and correct yourself, but I also think one should talk to the person on the side later and have a conversation on how they prefer you handle it. Communication goes a long way.

Another thing on disrespecting people's pronouns when you're mad at them: It makes it seem like a privilege to have the correct pronouns used. Like i'm good with you right now so i'll call you by what you want. But now i'm mad at you so you don't deserve the right pronouns. It also can make the person who is trans afraid to fight back because they know that if they say something against you, you'll hurt them emotionally by using the other pronouns/birth name. So if you're hurting them they won't say anything so that they don't get hurt more. This can be really damaging to their mental state.

I've always identified as a gender superior to all other genders. My beauty is such that I can pass as the absolute standard of beauty for all genders. I just went by he - him - his because it seemed practical. Given my superiority in beauty and intellect I will start demanding that lesser people address me as YHWH, which is one of the names of God in the Kabbalah.

I just started referring to everyone as 'person' or their name. It works better than stating gender because not everyone is a he or she strictly. I can't remember all those pronouns, i can barely remember what i did two days ago, lol.

What about other pronouns besides he, they, or she? I have multiple people in my life (ages ranging from 15-45) who use ze/zir or ze/hir pronouns. I think its really important now to educate about pronouns outside of the binary. And since they/them pronouns are more well-known now, we need to start talking about other pronouns. I use they/them pronouns and its definitely more difficult for the people in my life who use ze/zir or ze/hir pronouns because its less known and people respect it even less, thinking that its a "made up word". All language is made up. All language has been developed in order to reflect our social world. Language is constantly evolving. All pronouns should be respected if those pronouns resonate with that person. A lot of people don't know how to use ze/zir pronouns and use "they" as a replacement. "They" is not that persons pronouns, so take the time to learn how to use ze/zir or whatever other pronoun that person goes by. Also, one of our trans elders, Leslie Feinberg, used ze/hir pronouns. We gotta know our history!
Trans folk are beautiful people no matter how they started to when they transitioned, they are gorgeous inside and out and all of you are BEAUTIFUL!!

Those who I know who are trans that I met as the pronoun they prefer I click with it so fast. I'd never make a huge scene out of it I would apologize and explain it would take me time to get used to the different pronoun and they understood. But once I got it, it was so much easier. Honestly misgendering by accident even made me feel really guilty about it, because I dislike hurting my friends my misgendering. But this helps SO MUCH because holy shit Chase. I'm so glad you made that last statement on that with it being OK if you mess up, we'll make it click it just takes time!

Oh I want to add something very important : if you are a trans person and you misgender yourself in your head or out loud : IT'S OK. It doesn't mean you're not trans or not trans enough. It's normal to slip up because you've been the person that have been referred by your old pronouns during this all time, it can take time to adjust. I still call myself my old name and pronouns in my head sometimes.

Going back to the beginning of your video, you stated (paraphrase):

"It's important to gender a person correctly so they feel they pass as the gender."

In the event the person does not pass and in public the person is misgendered, how do you feel this situation should be handled? Also, if a trans person asks, "do I pass," is it ok to tell them "no," in the event they don't yet pass (of course using the proper pronouns regardless)? I work with trans kids, many who don't pass, but constantly asked, "do I pass?" I personally feel honesty is important here to not set them up for disappointment in "the real world." This has actually become such an issue we've had to ban the question, "do I pass?"

It's funny how much people get hung up on they "not being grammatically correct" because you do it ALL THE TIME when you don't know someone's gender. Like I work in a doctor's office and if the receptionist comes back and says "I have a patient that needs a print out of their past charges." my immediate response would be "Do they want certains dates or all of it." We are talking about a singular person but since i don't know the name or gender of the patient, i automatically use "they". Everyone does it all day long (at least in English) but then argue that you can't use it to refer to one person. It's only because they know what gender the person was assigned at birth that they have trouble wrapping their head around it.

I want to give a representation of pronouns as far as my life. I've literally been misgendered sense infancy. My mom has always corrected people that I was male sense I could remember. Growing up I used to do the same thing until I got older when I stopped correcting people about my pronouns. I've answered to both pronouns and I've used both pronouns to describe myself. I've embraced both pronouns because I'm seen as both pronouns. The empowerment comes from the correct usage of pronouns. In the beginning of my life I can understand how pronouns really do effect yo as a child growing up and why the correct pronouns gives affirmation and validation to that individual. It's always phenomenal to be called your correct pronouns and it's confirmation that your being supported. With neutral pronouns I've personally not used them yet because I've not met a gender neutral person but I welcome them when I do meet them. üòä

I don't know if you'll ever get this, but I'm a grad student--an old grad student--far removed from this generation.  I have been following you, Stef, and Ty, and learning so much.   I am in clinical psych, and I know the LGBT community has such a high vulnerability for depression and suicide.  Before providing therapy to anyone, you must be competent, and that means knowing their culture, race, background, and identity.  I know you are in the field of social work, and I think you are doing a great job furthering the education of the LBGT community to both young people feeling dysphoric (most important), but also for people like me, who do not know the trials and tribulations of being gay, transgender, or somewhere in between. 

Thank you for your work, your honesty, and for pushing through the depression and anxiety you often struggle with, to make these videos and reach out to people.  You are making a difference.

I think your honesty here is really amazing, I feel like people get so scared they're going to offend others by not getting pronouns correct straight away, so often they don't even try. So letting people know that it's natural to slip up, especially if you've known that person for a long time, is so helpful. As long as you respectfully correct yourself it's okay, and it's nice to show that person that you are making a conscious effort to use their correct pronouns, you just slipped up a little this time; it's okay it happens to a lot of people, even those within the community, we're not all magical pronoun unicorns, although that would be amazing ü¶Ñüåà

I find the last part about mentally practicing pronouns incredibly helpful. I use they  / them pronouns myself, but it's still  difficult for me to get peoples pronouns right spontaneously at times. My brain just still associates certain characteristics with he / she pronouns and I am still trying to undo this automatic mental connection. Picturing peoples' faces while forming sentences with the right pronouns works well for me.

Important:

Purposely misgendering a trans person because you are annoyed at them / dislike them is never acceptable. It is transphobic. Using someone's pronouns correctly is not an act of kindness - it's just something you do.
If you were annoyed at a cisgender man, you wouldn't call him "she", would you? So don't do it with a transgender man.
It's not just offensive to that person, but to the entire transgender community, as it shows you only respect trans people's identities when you want to and shows that you think correct pronouns are something transgender people have to earn.

I went to a PFLAG support meeting as an FTM person and heard a great way for dealing with people using the wrong pronoun (probably for people you are close to) called the ouch/oops. So if a person uses the wrong pronoun the individual can calmly say "ouch" to indicate that they were hurt by it and then the person who used the incorrect pronoun can then say "oops" and correct themselves, not making a big deal about it. Thanks again for all of these videos!!!

Good video. I'm autistic, and when I talk, I often jumble pronouns in my sentences. I hate that I misgender people like that, but unless I talk very slowly, and concentrate, I can't help it. I've explained this to a few friends, and they understand, and know that when I do that, I'm not misgendering, just getting mixed up. But for most people, I just say, "sorry, pronouns are hard" and they get confused, because "you use they pronouns though, shouldn't you get this?" and I do! I wish to god I was better able to control the words coming out of my mouth, but it's so hard. I guess I'm looking for tips? Not sure, just thought this would be a good place to say all this.

Just a fun fact - in Denmark you would call a stranger or someone with a higher rank as you (teacher, boss, etc.) them or they, in older times. To this day you are not allowed to call the royal family you or her/him, because that means you are close to them in some way. Doesnt really have anything to do with this subject, but its not a whole new thing, to not call people, in general by their genders.
